A potential combination of Bovis and Galliford Try's housing and partnership businesses we believe risks pushing back the timing of the margin improvement originally targeted by Bovis. As such, until the market hears evidence of the greater upside potential the deal brings, the risk/reward in the stock may appear less attractive.

Bovis Homes Group PLC (BVS:LSE): Last: 1,017, down 42 (-3.97%), High: 1,070, Low: 1,000, Volume: 202.58k
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Bovis has announced it has re-engaged in prelim talks with Galliford Try to combine Bovis and Galliford Try's housebuilding (Linden) and partnerships divisions. The total value of the deal is £1075m, of which Galliford shareholders would receive £675m of Bovis shares (equivalent to market cap of yesterday) and Galliford would receive £300m of cash with Bovis also taking on Galliford's 10 year £100m private placing (Galliford shareholders would own c£29.3% of Bovis).

With EBIT consensus forecasts for the Galliford businesses being bought appearing to range from £180-208m, this suggests the deal price to be c6.5-7.5x after tax earnings - approximately in line with valuations in the sector (albeit with Bovis PE and P/NTAV in line with sector, but margins yet to achieve that level it can be argued its 'currency' already contains a premium). Of the £400m of debt in the deal (£300m cash to Galliford and taking on of placement), c£140m is targeted to be raised by Bovis from a potential 9.9% share placing and £60m from paying the planned capital return later this year in shares rather than cash.

Istrain How can Bovis get away with saying that a bonus issue of £60m of shares is a capital return!!!
estrangedcapitalist Ello chaps
Upaswellasdown Is that you tube video for real?
BE11:18am

We see the rationale for the deal as the opportunity to buy inexpensive assets well known by the current CEO, bringing Bovis larger market share, speeding up the development of Bovis's partnership business as well as the potential for cost savings. However, we believe the market will question the timing of such a large deal at this stage in the cycle given all the political and economic uncertainties.

BE11:22am

For Bovis Homes, as we stated at the time of the previous approach, we can see the strategic logic of the proposed combination. It would immediately increase the scale of its housing business (Bovis & Linden Homes would deliver c.7,000 to 8,000 units) and is expected to deliver some synergies (as yet not quantified). It would also accelerate the Group's entry into the attractive and fast growing Partnerships and Regeneration business. Obviously, Greg Fitzgerald, the current CEO of Bovis was the former CEO of Galliford Try and therefore should know the business well. Partially funding the deal with shares and using an equity placing (up to 9.99% of Bovis existing share capital) as well as using a bonus issue for £60m of the share returns, would ensure that Bovis's balance sheet remains strong with a relatively conservative level of financial risk. It would leave Galliford Try with a stronger, well capitalsed balance sheet and a focused Construction business from which it could deliver value. There remain several hurdles to overcome before the deal completes, but it looks very likely to do so in our view.

marktime I hope you are right Mouselet
hornblower any grey on IP Group results and lack of strategy
Irish HF guy I find Takeaway.com buying Just eat for 52% of the merged entity as amazing, Just Eat contributes £72m of combined £74m EBITDA and 74% of turnover
11:22 am
BE11:22am

And Liberum.

BE11:22am

Bovis’s offer of £1.05bn represents a PER of around 6.4x for the housing businesses, broadly similar to multiples at which the smaller housebuilders trade, although the exposure to partnerships and regeneration (social housing contractor) should mean the businesses are valued at a premium to the less diverse small builders. The sale should appeal to shareholders as it enables them to realise the value in the group, as the construction division is now recapitalised.

Galliford shareholders will be left with 0.57 Bovis shares (worth 585p at 1019p) for each Galliford share and a share in the remainder of the Group, which will be a construction business making around £10m EBIT, with potential to get to £30m and net cash (on an average basis) of around £150m. Even on a pessimistic view this should be worth at least £150m (or 135p per share). This package should be worth around 720p per share.

Galliford Try’s shareholders should also benefit from the synergies that can be achieved from merging Bovis and Galliford’s housing businesses. Galliford holders end up with 29% of the enlarged Bovis group and could share in synergies worth around £20m (historic transactions in the sector delivered synergies at around 3% of sales) – capitalising 29% of £20m at 10x might make this component worth around another 43p.

Galliford’s shares trade at 672p per share which is not quite consistent with a £150m valuation of the rump and the value of Bovis shares received and does not reflect the synergies, or a re-rating for Bovis or the potential revaluation of the construction division as it recovers.

BE11:23am

The attraction of buying Galliford's housing businesses is that it will add scale to Bovis' housebuilding activities but that it will also diversify the product offering and the geographic scope of the business. Galliford’s partnerships and regeneration business is well placed in a growing part of the market, bringing higher growth and boosting return on capital, as it is capital light.

The acquisition could enhance earnings by around 20% before synergies, and perhaps up to 30% with synergies. The enhancement is so large as the business is being acquired in large part for cash and as Bovis's shares are trading at a higher multiple than it is paying for Galliford's housing businesses.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Consensus expects net cash at Bovis at the year end of around £200m, which would become net debt of around £60m after the £400m outflow to Galliford shareholders and the benefit of a 9.99% placing (13.4m shares at 1000p, for calculation purposes).

BE11:24am

At last night’s close of 615p, Galliford’s shares traded at around 4.4x calendar 2019E PER, which in our view valued the group as if it were a pure contractor. The present value is consistent with valuing the rump at around £150m, only the value of cash in the business, and the Bovis shareholding. This looks conservative as this does not reflect potential earnings enhancement to Bovis (even before the benefit of synergies).

easyJet, IAG and Ryanair confirmed guidance at the conference. Nevertheless, headwinds remain (economy, geopolitics, currency and cost). For IAG, investor focus was on the strikes at British Airways but the company continues to stand behind its guidance that was given at the time of the 2Q results. Ryanair has also experienced strike action but it does not appear to have impacted outlook. The company continues to think it can deliver positive pricing over winter and ancillary revenue growth continues to do well. easyJet seems comfortable with full year guidance and the turnaround of Berlin Tegel. Guidance was maintained.

Acknowledging the globalization of the industry, this report takes a quarterly look at capacity conditions and trends across the most important regions of the world. It also aims to highlight the exposure/strategy of the different major players in order to anticipate profit trends (with a summary of relative positions shown in Figure 1). Airline earnings and, in turn, share prices, are highly influenced by industry capacity and competing capacity for individual carriers. Following is an analysis of y/y changes in seats over the past 9 quarters and scheduled changes through 1Q20 with U.S. carrier trends shown through February 2020 with Southwest schedules only available through March 6, 2020 at the time of writing. Of note, schedules are most reliable two to three months out and only somewhat reliable four to six months out.

Air France-KLM (Hold): Offer on Aigle Azur While AF FP’s share price tumbled yesterday, the impact on the bonds was limited in a (limited) downward credit market. The explanation behind the fall was poor August traffic figures and an offer made on Aigle Azur, though at this stage we do not know if it is a total or partial offer.
Our base case is a partial offer focused on some Paris Orly slots (to avoid
any increase in competition) and on some staff (pilots). We expect no
downgrade (or perhaps a very limited one) of Air France-KLM’s credit
quality linked to Aigle Azur. As for the poor summer traffic, we add a stilllimited visibility on the group’s new CEO strategy. However, it triggers
no change in our Hold recommendation.

BE11:47am

Nomor's operations are concentrated in two countries, Norway and Sweden, where its main competitors are private equity owned Anticimex and Rentokil (SERV and Anticimex = 90% Swedish market and SERV, RTO and Anticimex = 85% Norway market). Separately, we also highlight that recently, as part of the CMA's investigation into Rentokil's acquisition of Mitie's pest control business in the UK, it was announced that Rentokil had offered to enter into an agreement with ServiceMaster to sell some of the assets.We continued to see Rentokil as a core holding for investors given steady organic growth potential, margin upside and astute capital allocation with a track record of creating value through M&A. Downside risk is limited, in our view. Whilst the competitive landscape may slowly be evolving with ServiceMaster's move into Europe, we do not believe this will impact Rentokil's ability to grow profitably and sustainably. The group's differentiated, digitally enabled go-to market strategy focused on service excellence and product innovation is a key point of differentiation. And to put things into perspective, Nomor is a $60m of sales business (c.£50m) vs Rentokil achieving over £1.4bn of sales in Europe. Following a strong share price outperformance, Rentokil's share price is closing in on our target price. We will review this in due course.

BE11:53am

IP Group’s H1 2019 results, published this morning, showed a very modest decline in hardNAV to GBP1,171.8m (GBp110.6/share) from GBP1,217.5m at FY 2018 (GBp115.0/share).
Overall, the portfolio made encouraging gains in important assets – Istesso and First Light Fusion – which were broadly offset by somewhat disappointing news from therapeutics businesses PsiOxus and Autifony. Crucially, the company has displayed effective cost controls, decreasing cash-burn. Furthermore, as management targeted at the start of the year, cash realisations have markedly increased. Year-to-date, IP Group has realised GBP45.9m of cash, already significantly in excess of the GBP29.5m in FY 2018, which will leave the company in a better-than-expected year-end cash position, in our view.

BE11:53am

Catalysts remain clear: We continue to expect a number of near-term catalysts that could drive a meaningful NAV increase, restore investor optimism and perhaps prompt the stock to re-rate towards its historical price-to-NAV levels. Firstly, and most importantly, we expect Oxford Nanopore to raise further funding in the next c6 months to accelerate growth. We anticipate a valuation uplift to the previous round, which could lead to a material NAV boost for IP Group, in our view, given that Oxford Nanopore is its largest holding (24.3% of NAV). Secondly, we expect First Light Fusion, which has now built the “Machine 3”, to demonstrate fusion in late 2019, in line with management’s expectations. This would open up the company’s path to a net energy gain in 3-4 years, as well as the potential to attract substantial third-party validation capital and ultimately drive IP Group’s NAV. Lastly, following Istesso’s positive phase II results, we expect Johnson & Johnson’s Janssen division to decide whether to exercise its option over the coming months.

BornCynic Dave West - he hired Chris Evans to go on a booze cruise and shop at his place in Calais - Eastenders. Front page of the FT states that the booze cruise will be back.
11:53 am
BE11:54am

Private portfolio alright; public markets still weak: The main drivers of the NAV in this half were Istesso, which gained GBP24.7m fair value after a successful phase II. This was followed by First Light Fusion, which gained GBP10.4m after a recent revaluation (for the first time since 2015). On the flip side, PsiOxus faced a GBP10.9m fair value reduction due to Bristol-Meyers Squibb (BMS) handing back the rights to its oncolytic virus. Autifony’s fair value also declined, by GBP7.1m, after its programmes were assessed and the likelihood of Boehringer Ingelheim executing its option was re-evaluated. The quoted portfolio continued to come under pressure in the half and was down by GBP20.4m. Further to management’s portfolio rationalisation efforts, the company has fully exited Circassia, realising GBP4.3m.

BE11:54am

External funding raises confidence: The company reported healthy external funding rounds for Inivata (GBP40m), Featurespace (GBP25m) and Azuri Technologies (GBP20m). The ability of the portfolio companies to continue raising these levels of funding gives us confidence in the underlying portfolio value. It also indicates to us that the funding burden on IP Group is further decreasing. Moreover, we are encouraged that a large number of multinational corporates, including Amgen and Bosch, have recently participated in funding rounds.

BE11:56am

Conclusion: The 4% 1H NAV decline would need to slow during 2H to hit our 109p YE estimate, and the reduction in net cash to £71m and 1H outflow rate will raise concerns of funding requirements to avoid net debt during 1Q20, although the realisation rate has increased to £39m since June (£7.1m in 1H) mainly through sales of Oxford and Cambridge VC fund stakes. The pick up in realisations offers some comfort, as do opex reductions, but no new news on Oxford Nanopore's planned IPO (or private round during 2H) or a broader strategic reboot we had hoped for. News: 1H NAV/share ex goodwill was 110.6p, down 4% vs. end 2018. Net cash £71m, net outflow of £50.2m during 1H. Gross cash and deposits £161.1m. Cash opex ~ £15m in 1H.

BE12:00pm

H1 19 revenue growth in the UK was a remarkable 23%. Today’s meeting highlighted that this was being achieved through implementing product and operational changes, while adhering to responsible gaming obligations. We expect this approach of providing support to accelerate growth in other markets will be sufficient to more than offset challenges elsewhere.

BE12:06pm

888’s H1 19 results are in-line with our bullish outlook coming out of
the June CMD. 888 reported an organic/LFL revenue increase of 7%
organic y/y (JPMe +5.3%). Pre-IFRS 16 adjusted EBITDA was $41.8m,
1.5% above JPMe $41.2m, representing a decline of 35% y/y (primarily
due to pre-flagged P&L investment and gaming duties). Growth was
driven by Sport and Casino in vertical terms, and by the continued
recovery in the UK in geographic terms. We remain Overweight, and roll
forward our PT to Dec 2020, leaving it at 220p. We expect the share price
to react positively today.
 As discussed at the CMD, the UK (35% of Group revenue)
continues to exhibit exceptionally strong growth with +23% LFL in
H1 19, driven by 888’s pivot to recreational customers. UK B2C was
+31% on a LFL basis in H1 19, with both Casino and Sport greater than +50% in
the period. We calculate that UK B2C growth may have been as high as
~45% y/y in Q2 19, and despite an easier comp (due to the Q2 18
revenue step down) was still ~+15% q/q sequentially. This growth
appears to have slowed sequentially in Q3, based on a total UK revenue
increase of ~24% y/y, but nonetheless the YTD performance is
impressive.

BE12:06pm

Casino and Sport continue to be the key growth verticals. Casino
(63%) was +14% y/y at cc (JPMe: +12%). The introduction of the
Casino Orbit platform (May in the UK, followed by other markets) and
the shift towards casual customers led to Casino actives +30% y/y, while
revenue per player declined by 16%. 888 has reiterated its aspiration to
be “the world’s dominant online Casino brand”. Sport (16%) delivered
28% cc revenue growth (vs. JPMe 25%), against a comp that includes
part of the World Cup. The rollout of the group’s first proprietary
sportsbook is starting in early 2020.
 Poker (8%) has stabilized and is poised for a return to growth. H1
19 revenue declined by 24% (JPMe -29%), but increased by 26% vs. H2
18, supported by the roll-out of Poker 8 in some regulated markets and
in particular boosted by 38% growth in Italy.
 888’s outlook is for a FY19E outturn “in-line with its [prior]
expectations”. We forecast ~6% group organic in H2, consistent with the
current trading run rate of +9% cc (with 2/3% of acquisition
contribution). We maintain our pre-IFRS 16 FY19E/FY20E EBITDA
at $85m/$94m, which now equates to $91m/$99m under IFRS 16.
